metadata.titleEn: Multi-scale dataset of environment and element-at-risk for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau
metadata.description: The multi-scale dataset of environment and element-at-risk for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau  includes geomorphic data, normalized vegetation index data, annual temperature and rainfall data, and disaster bearing value grade data, covering an area of 6.56 million square kilometers. The data set is mainly prepared for disaster and risk assessment. Due to the huge coverage, the geomorphic data adopts 150m spatial resolution and other data adopts 1000m spatial resolution. Geomorphology, vegetation index, temperature and rainfall data are mainly produced by processing open source data, and disaster bearing value grade data are produced by superposition calculation, comprehensively considering population data, night light index, buildings and surface cover types.

background: Spatially interpolated gridded climate data, here referred to as 'climate surfaces', are used in many areas of work, particularly in the environmental, agricultural and biological sciences. For many applications, data at a high (≤1km2) spatial resolution are preferred to capture environmental variation that can be lost at lower spatial resolutions, particularly in mountainous and other areas with steep climate gradients. Hijmans et al. (2005) provided climate surfaces, referred to as the ‘WorldClim version 1 database’, for global land areas (excluding Antarctica), consisting of long-term average monthly temperature and precipitation. Over the past decade, there has been an increase in the number of climate stations for which data is available, including a number of stations located at high latitudes and elevations. Furthermore, while the original dataset was limited to monthly precipitation and temperature, we also included solar radiation, wind speed and vapour pressure, which may be necessary to model important processes such as plant growth. Estimates for regions where weather station density (or quality) is insufficient to resolve local gradients may be improved using remotely sensed meteorological data from satellites.
research objective: We also wanted to improve estimates for areas with low station density and in areas with unusual gradients (inversions) and sharp gradients such as rain-shadows or abrupt temperature changes due to ocean-land transitions. We examined the utility of including satellite-derived and other covariables (distance to coast, extraterrestrial solar radiation) for interpolating several climate variables across global land areas.
challenges: The fact that most of our climate surface estimates were only marginally improved by use of satellite covariates highlights the importance of having a dense, high-quality network of climate station data. Prediction error remained high in such regions for all climate variables.
methods: Weather station data were interpolated using thin-plate splines with covariates including elevation, distance to the coast and three satellite-derived covariates: maximum and minimum land surface temperature as well as cloud cover, obtained with the MODIS satellite platform. Interpolation was done for 23 regions of varying size depending on station density. We compiled monthly average climate data for weather stations from a large number of global, regional, national, and local sources, mostly for the 1970–2000 period. Utilizing satellite-derived data and other covariables, we interpolated these data using the thin-plate smoothing spline algorithm implemented in ANUSPLIN and created global climate surfaces for monthly precipitation and minimum, mean, and maximum temperature, solar radiation, wind speed and vapour pressure. Final surfaces were created by selecting only the model with the lowest cross-validation RMSE value for each region, fit to the full dataset.
dataset: We created a new dataset of spatially interpolated monthly climate data for global land areas at a very high spatial resolution (approximately 1km2). We included monthly temperature (minimum, maximum and average), precipitation, solar radiation, vapour pressure and wind speed, aggregated across a target temporal range of 1970–2000, using data from between 9000 and 60000 weather stations.
findings: Global cross-validation correlations were ≥0.99 for temperature and humidity, 0.86 for precipitation and 0.76 for wind speed.

background: The digital data archive of nighttime lights was first established at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) National Geophysical Data Center (NGDC) in 1992. Studies focusing on the application of nighttime lights have flourished since the publication of annual stable lights based upon DMSP-OLS by the NOAA Earth Observation Group (EOG). In the last few years, the EOG has processed and published nighttime lights from the VIIRS, which flown on the satellite launched in 2011. Some new features of VIIRS lights data include monthly updates, higher resolution, and better overall quality. Testing the applicability of new VIIRS lights in estimating economic statistics provides an important initial step. It is well known that economic development significantly influences and is highly correlated with inequality, poverty, public health, migration, urbanization, and a wide range of social phenomenon. The inquiry of the GDP-light association started when DMSP-OLS lights first became available. In the last decade, over a thousand publications have used DMSP-OLS lights to predict economic activities. These studies were important because, unlike conventional economic statistics provided by governments or international organizations, which are often inconsistent in timeframe, definition, and measurement instrument employed, nighttime lights have the advantage of being objectively measured, updated regularly, and cover the entire globe (except for at high latitudes). Additionally, lights data avoid systematic errors due to government misreporting or differences in methods, and this may make them a more reliable source in predicting true GDP values at the global, national, and local levels. The availability of DMSP-OLS annual stable lights from 1992 to 2013 allows researchers to investigate the GDP-lights relationship with cross-sectional and time series data during 1990s and 2010s. In general, the results suggest the DMSP-OLS lights are useful for cross-sectional analysis, but it may not provide enough information to predict time series economic statistics.
research objective: Our goal is to test the GDP-lights association using the new VIIRS lights data. The focus is US GDP statistics, as these are relatively accurate accounts of economic output compared to the statistics reported in many other countries.
methods: To test the association between VIIRS light and GDP, we use VIIRS light to predict 2014 to 2016 real GDP (as chained 2009 dollars) at both the state and metropolitan statistical area (MSA) level. The GDP data by state and MSA are downloaded from the official website of the U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis. For VIIRS lights, we use annual data for the corresponding time periods, i.e. annual average lights for 2014–2016. To generate consistent measure of annual VIIRS lights, we use averaged monthly composites as an annual light measure for 2014, 2015, and 2016. The digital values of VIIRS lights are aggregated at the state and metropolitan levels and then merged with real GDP by the administrative unit. We use linear regression to estimate the relationship between VIIRS and state and MSA GDP (both are measured logarithmically to correct for heteroskedasticity).
dataset: The GDP data by state and MSA are downloaded from the official website of the U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis. The state and MSA samples include annual GDP for 50 states plus the District of Columbia and of 381 MSAs. For VIIRS lights, we use annual data for the corresponding time periods, i.e. annual average lights for 2014–2016.
findings: Focusing on both US states and metropolitan statistical areas (MSAs), we found that the VIIRS lights are more useful in predicting cross-sectional GDP than predicting time-series GDP data. Additionally, the present analysis shows that high-resolution VIIRS lights provide a better prediction for MSA GDP than for state GDP, which suggests that lights may be more closely related to urban sectors than rural sectors. The results also indicate the importance of considering biases that may arise from different aggregations (the modifiable areal unit problems, MAUP) in applications of nighttime lights in understanding socioeconomic phenomenon.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of how satellite-derived data is utilized to improve climate data interpolation in regions with low weather station density?
Example.Answer: Satellite-derived data, such as maximum and minimum land surface temperature and cloud cover obtained with the MODIS satellite platform, are used as covariates in the interpolation of weather station data using thin-plate splines. This method is applied to create high-resolution climate surfaces, particularly in areas with low station density or unusual climate gradients.

This approach helps in analyzing the relationship between nighttime lights and economic output at different administrative levels.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'spatially interpolated gridded climate data' in the context of environmental datasets?
Definition.Answer: Spatially interpolated gridded climate data, referred to as 'climate surfaces', are datasets used in various fields such as environmental, agricultural, and biological sciences. These datasets are generated by interpolating weather station data using methods like thin-plate splines, combined with covariates such as elevation and satellite-derived data, to create high-resolution climate estimates across global land areas.

Definition.Question: What is the concept of 'cross-validation RMSE value' in the context of creating datasets?
Definition.Answer: Cross-validation RMSE value is a metric used to assess the accuracy of interpolated climate surfaces by evaluating the model's predictive error across different regions. It involves selecting the model with the lowest RMSE value after cross-validation, ensuring the best fit to the full dataset for regions with varying station density.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the methodologies for predicting economic statistics using nighttime lights data differ between the DMSP-OLS and VIIRS datasets, and how do these differences influence the reliability of predictions?
Comparison.Answer: The VIIRS dataset offers higher resolution and quality, allowing for better prediction of economic statistics at finer scales, such as metropolitan areas, compared to the DMSP-OLS dataset. This suggests VIIRS lights are more closely related to urban economic activities, while DMSP-OLS may be less effective for time-series economic statistics.

Interpretation.Question: How might integrating satellite-derived data improve the accuracy of spatially interpolated climate surfaces in regions with steep climate gradients?
Interpretation.Answer: Integrating satellite-derived data such as maximum and minimum land surface temperature and cloud cover can potentially enhance the accuracy of climate surfaces, especially in regions with steep climate gradients where station density is low. However, the improvement in estimates using satellite covariates is often marginal, highlighting the need for a dense network of high-quality climate station data.

Interpretation.Question: What are the potential challenges in using nighttime lights data to predict economic activities across different geographic scales?
Interpretation.Answer: A key challenge in using nighttime lights data to predict economic activities across different geographic scales is the modifiable areal unit problem (MAUP), which can introduce biases in the analysis. Nighttime lights data may be more effective in predicting urban economic activities compared to rural areas due to closer ties between lights and urban sectors. Additionally, while lights data provide a consistent and objective measure, they may not be sufficient for time series economic predictions.

Interpretation.Question: What implications do variations in spatial resolution have on capturing environmental variations in datasets covering vast geographic areas?
Interpretation.Answer: Variations in spatial resolution can significantly impact the ability to capture environmental variations in large geographic areas. High spatial resolution (≤1km2) is preferred for capturing detailed environmental changes, especially in mountainous regions with steep climate gradients. Lower spatial resolutions may result in a loss of critical detail, which can affect the effectiveness of datasets used for environmental, agricultural, and biological applications.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for high spatial resolution in datasets used for disaster and risk evaluation on the Tibetan Plateau and its surrounding areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: High spatial resolution is needed to capture environmental variation that can be lost at lower spatial resolutions, especially in mountainous areas with steep climate gradients. This is crucial for accurate disaster and risk evaluation.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why do nighttime lights data provide a more reliable source for predicting GDP compared to conventional economic statistics?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Nighttime lights data are objectively measured, updated regularly, cover the entire globe, and avoid systematic errors due to government misreporting or differences in methods, making them potentially more reliable for predicting GDP values.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the prediction error remaining high when using satellite covariates for climate data interpolation?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The prediction error remains high due to the importance of having a dense, high-quality network of climate station data, which is not completely offset by the use of satellite covariates.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of integrating high-resolution satellite-derived data with traditional climate station data in enhancing the accuracy of climate variable predictions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating high-resolution satellite-derived data with traditional climate station data could potentially improve estimates for areas with low station density and unusual gradients. However, it may not significantly enhance predictions if the climate station network is not dense and of high quality. The use of additional covariables like satellite data could refine interpolations, but the primary challenge remains the availability and quality of the station data.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the usage of nighttime lights data affect the interpretation of socioeconomic phenomena when combined with traditional economic statistics?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The usage of nighttime lights data, when combined with traditional economic statistics, can provide a more objective measure and help address inconsistencies in timeframe, definition, and measurement in conventional data. Nighttime lights data avoid systematic errors from government misreporting and can enhance predictions of GDP, particularly in cross-sectional analysis. However, it may introduce aggregation biases, such as the modifiable areal unit problem, which need to be considered in socioeconomic analyses.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of creating a dataset that encompasses geomorphological data, normalized vegetation index data, and average annual temperature and rainfall for risk assessment in a large geographical area?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to conduct disaster and risk evaluation, considering the vast coverage area of 656,000 square kilometers, which requires detailed data to assess the potential for disaster, the factors that contribute to it, and the susceptibility of the regions involved.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to use high-resolution spatially interpolated climate data when studying environmental variations in regions with steep climate gradients?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Using high-resolution spatially interpolated climate data is important because it helps capture environmental variations that can be overlooked at lower spatial resolutions, especially in mountainous areas with steep climate gradients, enabling more accurate modeling of climatic impacts on environmental and biological processes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended benefits of employing nighttime lights data for economic analysis, such as predicting GDP in various regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intended benefits of using nighttime lights data for economic analysis include providing an objective and consistent measure of economic activity, which can overcome limitations of conventional economic statistics like inconsistent reporting methods and potential biases, thereby offering a more reliable estimation of economic outputs at different geographic scales.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can satellite-derived data be used to improve climate estimates in regions with low weather station density?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Satellite-derived data, such as land surface temperature and cloud cover obtained from satellite platforms, can be used as covariates in interpolation models to help estimate climate variables in regions with sparse weather station data. These satellite covariates, alongside other variables like elevation and distance to coast, are incorporated into the interpolation process to help capture local climate variations and improve estimates.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used to test the association between VIIRS nighttime lights data and GDP at different geographical levels?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To test the association, VIIRS lights data is used to predict GDP at the state and metropolitan statistical area (MSA) levels. The GDP data is downloaded from official sources, and annual average VIIRS lights data is aggregated at the state and MSA levels. Linear regression is then used to estimate the relationship between VIIRS lights and GDP, with both measures logarithmically transformed to correct for heteroskedasticity.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enable the integration of satellite-derived covariates in interpolating climate data for regions with low station density?
Enablement.Answer: Satellite-derived covariates, such as maximum and minimum land surface temperature and cloud cover obtained with the MODIS satellite platform, enable the interpolation of climate data for regions with low station density by providing additional data points that can improve the accuracy of climate models in these areas.

Enablement.Question: What conditions facilitate the production of datasets that combine geophysical, vegetation, and socio-economic data for large geographical areas?
Enablement.Answer: The production of such datasets is facilitated by combining open-source data for geophysical, vegetation, temperature, and rainfall information with socio-economic data through calculated indices like the night-time lights index, and considering factors like population data, building distribution, and land cover types at varied spatial resolutions, enabling comprehensive risk assessment and disaster evaluation over extensive regions.

Expectation.Question: Why might the integration of satellite-derived covariates only marginally improve climate surface estimates in certain regions?
Expectation.Answer: The integration of satellite-derived covariates might only marginally improve climate surface estimates in certain regions due to the importance of having a dense, high-quality network of climate station data. Prediction error remains high in regions with insufficient station density or quality, regardless of satellite data usage.

Expectation.Question: Why is the prediction accuracy of high-resolution VIIRS lights data potentially more effective for urban areas compared to rural areas?
Expectation.Answer: The prediction accuracy of high-resolution VIIRS lights data might be more effective for urban areas compared to rural areas because the lights are more closely related to urban sectors, where economic activities are more concentrated and visible through nighttime lights.

Expectation.Question: Why might the use of nighttime lights in predicting economic statistics be more reliable than traditional economic statistics?
Expectation.Answer: The use of nighttime lights in predicting economic statistics might be more reliable than traditional economic statistics because nighttime lights data avoid systematic errors due to government misreporting or differences in methods, providing a consistent and objective measure that is updated regularly and covers a wide geographic area.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the challenges involved in using satellite-derived data for improving climate variable estimates in regions with low station density?
Judgmental.Answer: The challenges in using satellite-derived data to improve climate variable estimates in regions with low station density include the fact that most climate surface estimates were only marginally improved by satellite covariates. This highlights the importance of having a dense, high-quality network of climate station data. Prediction error remained high for all climate variables in such regions.

Judgmental.Question: In your view, how do high-resolution VIIRS lights data contribute to understanding socioeconomic phenomena at different aggregation levels?
Judgmental.Answer: High-resolution VIIRS lights data contribute significantly to understanding socioeconomic phenomena, particularly at the metropolitan statistical area (MSA) level. The data is more closely related to urban sectors than rural sectors, which implies that it provides better predictions for MSA GDP than state GDP. This highlights the importance of considering biases from different aggregations, known as the modifiable areal unit problems (MAUP), in applications of nighttime lights.

Judgmental.Question: How would you assess the development of datasets covering large geographic areas, like the Tibetan Plateau, in terms of spatial resolution and data integration?
Judgmental.Answer: The development of datasets covering large geographic areas, such as the Tibetan Plateau, involves careful consideration of spatial resolution and data integration. The use of 150m spatial resolution for geomorphological data and 1000m for other data types reflects a balance between data granularity and the vast coverage area. Data integration involves processing open-source data for geomorphology, vegetation indices, and climate, while the disaster-bearing capacity data involves overlay calculations, considering population, nighttime lights, buildings, and land cover types.

Assertion.Question: I don’t understand how spatial resolution affects the accuracy of climate data predictions in mountainous regions.
Assertion.Answer: In mountainous regions, high spatial resolution (≤1km2) is preferred to capture environmental variations that can be lost at lower resolutions. This is particularly important for areas with steep climate gradients, such as rain-shadows or abrupt temperature changes due to ocean-land transitions.

Assertion.Question: I’m not sure why satellite-derived data are used in the interpolation of climate variables.
Assertion.Answer: Satellite-derived data are used in interpolation to improve estimates for areas with low station density and unusual gradients, such as inversions. These data can include variables like maximum and minimum land surface temperature and cloud cover, which help refine climate surface estimates where ground-based data alone may be insufficient.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand why nighttime lights data are considered reliable for predicting economic activities.
Assertion.Answer: Nighttime lights data are considered reliable because they are objectively measured, updated regularly, and cover the entire globe. They avoid systematic errors due to government misreporting or methodological differences, providing a more consistent basis for predicting GDP values at various geographic levels.

Request/Directive.Question: Please provide an analysis of the data collection methods used for obtaining geomorphological and vegetation index data in large-scale disaster risk assessments.
Request/Directive.Answer: Geomorphological and vegetation index data in large-scale disaster risk assessments are primarily collected by processing open-source datasets. The geomorphological data use a spatial resolution of 150m, while other data like the vegetation index are collected at a 1000m spatial resolution. This allows for detailed analysis within the large coverage area of 656 million square kilometers.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the challenges faced in using satellite-derived covariates for interpolating climate data in regions with low weather station density.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges include the fact that satellite-derived covariates only marginally improve climate surface estimates, highlighting the need for a dense, high-quality climate station network. Prediction errors remain high in regions with low station density, unusual gradients, or sharp gradients such as rain-shadow areas or abrupt temperature changes due to ocean-land transitions.
